Yes, I believe so. Perhaps something similar to the niching mechanism 
in g=
enerational NEAT, boosting younger species's fitness and 
penalizing old sp=
ecies. In Novelty Search this may be applied like.. 
If a species continiou=
sly produces novel forms, it is rewarded. If a 
species keeps prodicing the=
 same or close to the same known 
behaviors, then it can be penalized. 

Pe=
ter

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "joel278" <lehman.154@...> wrote:
>
> Sor=
ry, overlooked your last point about speciation.
> That is a good point, th=
at perhaps the fitness of the individuals is
> not as important as that of =
the overall species, since that will
> determine the amount of offspring a =
particular species gets.
> 
> So the bias then is to genotypic lines that h=
ave produced novelty in
> the past, which might be a good indicator of nove=
lty in the future.
> Maybe there is a way to reward species in a more princ=
ipled/explicit
> manner? 
> 
> Joel
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "joel=
278" <lehman.154@> wrote:
> >
> > Peter,
> > 
> > That is a surprising resu=
lt. It seems like never changing the 
novelty
> > scores would create attra=
ctors around old behaviors instead of new
> ones. 
> > 
> > For example, im=
agine an individual that reaches a new area in
> > behavioral space. It is =
assigned a high novelty score. Several new
> > individuals arrive in the sa=
me area, and get lower novelty scores 
(the
> > first one maintains its hig=
h score). What we want is to explore 
the
> > individuals on the 'fringe' o=
f this new area, in hopes of finding
> > further areas of novetly. However,=
 with constant novelty scores, 
the
> > bias will be to investigate the are=
a in the proximity of the first
> > individual, even though the ones on the=
 fringe may be more 
promising.
> > 
> > If you consistently get better per=
formance with constant novelty
> > scores over a variety of maps perhaps it=
 is worth looking into 
more.
> > 
> > Joel
> >

s.com, "petar_chervenski" 
<petar_chervenski@>

> > > Hi Jo=
el,

> > > Novelty search is one really inspiring idea. 
> > > It is =
interesting to note that when I added the dynamic 
adjustment of 
> > > the=
 sparseness/novelty score, the performance was actually 
worse than 
> > > =
without adjusting the novelty score, i.e. an individual always 
stays 
> > =
> with the novelty score it was born with. 
> > > I hypothesize that this i=
s because it encourages such species 
that 
> > > produce more novel behavi=
ors frequently. But I guess that the 
best 
> > > way is to recompute the n=
ovelty scores at regular intervals.. 
> > > 
> > > Peter

n neat@yahoogroups.com, "joel278" <lehman.154@> wrote:

eter,

and that 
you've

> > > > You ar=
e correct, the novelty of each individual is calculated 
with
> > > > respe=
ct to the current population and the archive.

> > > > Yes, sparsen=
ess in the behavioral space around an individual 
is
> > > > equated with n=
ovelty, which is used for the fitness of the 
> > > individual.
> > > > 
> =
> > > Ideally, novelty would recomputed for each individual in the 
current=

> > > > generation after each evaluation. In our implementation it is 
> >=
 > allowed
> > > > to get stale for a few evaluations (in the same frequenc=
y that
> > > > individuals are respeciated according to rtNEAT). In our 
> =
> > experiments,
> > > > allowing for a bit staleness did not effect the re=
sults.

> > > > Actually, in the scenario you describe, each of the=
 
individuals 
> > > would
> > > > now have a lower novelty, the original i=
ndividual included. 
This
> > > > reflects that the area around these indiv=
iduals in behavior 
space is
> > > > more dense than it previously was. As =
more individuals come 
into a
> > > > particular area, the novelty of all o=
f them drops, and 
provides
> > > > pressure for individuals to do somethin=
g new in order to be 
seen as 
> > > novel.
> > > > 
> > > > Let me know if=
 you have any more implementation questions, 
I'll be

source based off the rtNEAT package in the next 
few
